docs.lead_paragraph: The speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates rebuts an editorial criticizing recent bills before that body.

headline.main: Why Some Bills Are Popular in Virginia, and Beyond
headline.print_headline: Why Some Bills Are Popular in Virginia, and Beyond

docs.abstract: Letter from William Howell, the speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates, comments on the February 13 editorial on the American Legislative Exchange Council, a privately funded conservative organization that drafts model legislation that has been used by Republican lawmakers across the country.
docs.snippet: The speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates rebuts an editorial criticizing recent bills before that body.

headline.main: Santorum Defends Comments on Obama and Education

docs.abstract: Rick Santorum’s statements Saturday about the federal role in education and the “phony theology” of President Obama’s agenda reverberated on Sunday-morning talk shows.
docs.snippet: Rick Santorum’s statements Saturday about the federal role in education and the “phony theology” of President Obama’s agenda reverberated on Sunday-morning talk shows.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a decade after the first organ swap in the United States, the transplant world remains disjointed, as competing private registries operate with little government regulation.

headline.seo: Lack of Unified System Hampers Kidney Transplants
headline.main: Lack of Unified System Hampers Kidney Transplant Efforts
headline.print_headline: Lack of Unified System Hampers Transplant Efforts

docs.snippet: More than a decade after the first organ swap in the United States, the transplant world remains disjointed, as competing private registries operate with little government regulation.

docs.lead_paragraph: State and local entities all across the country issue municipal bonds, which are often their lifeblood. But not all are adapting well to a new, more open world.

headline.seo: Municipal Bonds Are Sometimes Still Lost in the Fog
headline.main: A Fog Warning, Again, for Municipal Bonds
headline.print_headline: A Fog Warning, Again, for Municipal Bonds

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column applauds efforts by the Securities and Exchange Commission to bring transparency to the $4 trillion municipal bond market, but warns that while disclosure among issuers has improved, getting the full picture remains difficult; cites case of West Penn Allegheny Health System, an issuer that has not adapted well to the new, open world.
docs.snippet: State and local entities all across the country issue municipal bonds, which are often their lifeblood. But not all are adapting well to a new, more open world.

docs.lead_paragraph: Your shopping habits reveal even the most personal information — like when you’re going to have a baby.
docs.abstract: Excerpt from Charles Duhigg book The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business describes how advances in the science of habit formation have made it possible for major retailers like Target to deduce consumers' personal information from their shopping habits.
docs.snippet: Your shopping habits reveal even the most personal information — like when you’re going to have a baby.

docs.lead_paragraph: Other priests may avoid the topic, but not the Rev. Roger J. Landry, who gives his parishioners the Catholic Church’s 80-proof doctrine, straight up.

headline.seo: Priest Argues Against Contraception, Without Apology
headline.main: The Message on Contraception, Without Apology
headline.print_headline: The Message on Contraception, Without Apology

docs.abstract: Mark Oppenheimer Beliefs column on Roman Catholic Rev Roger J Landry of New Bedford, Mass, whose opinion is without apology on the Obama administration's requirement that employee health insurance cover birth control; Landry, in contrast to many other parish priests, is a fervent believer in official Catholic teaching against contraception and is unafraid to say so.
docs.snippet: Other priests may avoid the topic, but not the Rev. Roger J. Landry, who gives his parishioners the Catholic Church’s 80-proof doctrine, straight up.

docs.lead_paragraph: With each party saying it pocketed an election-year victory, Congress voted to extend payroll tax cuts and unemployment benefits and sent the legislation to President Obama.

headline.seo: Congress Passes Tax Cut Extension and Jobless Aid
headline.main: Tax Cut Extension Passes; Everyone Claims a Win
headline.print_headline: Congress Passes Tax Cut Extension, and Everyone Claims a Win

docs.abstract: Congress votes to extend payroll tax cuts and unemployment benefits and sends the legislation to Pres Obama, ending a contentious policy fight; both parties claim the extensions as election-year victories.
docs.snippet: With each party saying it pocketed an election-year victory, Congress voted to extend payroll tax cuts and unemployment benefits and sent the legislation to President Obama.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and JENNIFER STEINHAUER

headline.main: The Options for Payment Reform in U.S. Health Care

docs.abstract: No simple method is available for reducing the cost of health care, and the various payment methods each have strengths and weaknesses, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: No simple method is available for reducing the cost of health care, and the various payment methods each have strengths and weaknesses, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The cuts, expected to be announced next week, will exacerbate a state health care system that is already plagued by fraud, inefficiency and unsustainable costs.

headline.seo: Illinois Medicaid Cuts Will Hit a System Already in Crisis
headline.main: Illinois Medicaid Cuts Will Hit a System Already in Crisis
headline.print_headline: Cuts Will Hit a System That Is Already in Crisis

docs.snippet: The cuts, expected to be announced next week, will exacerbate a state health care system that is already plagued by fraud, inefficiency and unsustainable costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of the rule mandating insurance coverage for birth control contend that some contraception methods amount to abortion, but experts say the drugs work prior to fertilization.

headline.seo: Religious Groups Equate Abortion With Some Contraceptives
headline.main: Religious Groups Equate Some Contraceptives With Abortion
headline.print_headline: Groups Equate Abortion With Some Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic bishops and some evangelical groups assert that plan to require that employees of religiously affiliated institutions must receive insurance coverage for birth control also effectively requires coverage of some forms of abortion because some contraceptives could potentially prevent the implantation of a fertilized egg.
docs.snippet: Opponents of the rule mandating insurance coverage for birth control contend that some contraception methods amount to abortion, but experts say the drugs work prior to fertilization.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and ERIK ECKHOLM
